name: zone
content:
zone

noun
 
 
/zəʊn/
 
/zəʊn/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1.  
     an area or a region with a particular feature or use
    • a war/combat/demilitarized/exclusion zone
    • a danger zone
    • a pedestrian zone (= where vehicles may not go)
    • They have called for a 100-mile buffer zone (= protected area) around the island to protect the seals.
    • an earthquake zone
    see also danger zone, hot zone, no-fly zone, red zone, time zone
    Extra Examples
    • Europe is divided into economic zones.
    • Most of the old town is a traffic-free zone.
    • Our truck was trapped in the kill zone.
    • She stood some distance away from him to maintain a safety zone.
    • The internet has become a free-fire zone for conspiracy theories.
    • The area has been declared a closed military zone.
    • The rebels control the southern border zone.
    • The region has been declared an ecological disaster zone.
    • This area behind the station is a no-go zone for tourists.
    • an industrial zone of factories, warehouses and shipyards
    • an oxygen-depleted dead zone at the bottom of the sea
    • the neutral zone between the two countries
    • Half a million people were made homeless throughout the earthquake zone.
    • The agreement provided for a security zone of 80km on both sides of the border.
    • The main part of the city centre is a pedestrian zone.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • narrow
    • wide
    • marginal
    • …
    verb + zone
    • control
    • patrol
    • create
    • …
    preposition
    • in a/​the zone
    • within a/​the zone
    • into a/​the zone
    • …
    See full entry
  2. one of the areas that a larger area is divided into for the purpose of organization
    • postal charges to countries in zone 2
    Extra Examples
    • All countries in zones 1 and 2 have free incoming calls.
    • The ticket may be used on any bus in zone 2.
  3. an area or a part of an object, especially one that is different from everything that is around it
    • When the needle enters the red zone the engine is too hot.
    • the erogenous zones of the body
    see also crumple zoneTopics Geographyb2
  4. one of the parts that the earth’s surface is divided into by imaginary lines that are parallel to the equator
    • the northern/southern temperate zone
    Wordfinder
    • arid
    • climate
    • continental climate
    • equatorial
    • frigid
    • harsh
    • humidity
    • rainfall
    • tropical
    • zone
    Extra Examples
    • This species is found widely distributed throughout the northern temperate zone.
    • the alpine and arid zones of Australia
    • The plant grows only in the temperate zone.
    • the temperate and tropical zones of South America
    • a transition zone between tropical and arid vegetations
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • narrow
    • wide
    • marginal
    • …
    verb + zone
    • control
    • patrol
    • create
    • …
    preposition
    • in a/​the zone
    • within a/​the zone
    • into a/​the zone
    • …
    See full entry
    5. Word Originlate Middle English: from French, or from Latin zona ‘girdle’, from Greek zōnē.
Idioms
in the zone
  1. (informal) in a state in which you feel confident and are performing at your best
    • When I'm in the zone, writing is the most satisfying thing in the world.
    see also comfort zone
a/the twilight world (of something) | the twilight zone
  1. a state in which things are strange, mysterious or secret; a state that exists on the dividing line between two things
    • the twilight world of the occult
    • The dissidents lived in a twilight world of hushed voices and secret meetings.
    • the twilight zone between living and merely existing
    • They lived in the twilight zone on the fringes of society.
See zone in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee zone in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: zone

name: zone
content:
zone

verb
 
/zəʊn/
 
/zəʊn/
[usually passive]
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they zone
 
/zəʊn/
 
/zəʊn/
he / she / it zones
 
/zəʊnz/
 
/zəʊnz/
past simple zoned
 
/zəʊnd/
 
/zəʊnd/
past participle zoned
 
/zəʊnd/
 
/zəʊnd/
-ing form zoning
 
/ˈzəʊnɪŋ/
 
/ˈzəʊnɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. to keep an area of land to be used for a particular purpose
    • be zoned (for something) The town centre was zoned for office development.
  2. to divide an area of land into smaller areas
    • be zoned (into something) The park has been zoned into four distinct areas.
    3. Word Originlate Middle English: from French, or from Latin zona ‘girdle’, from Greek zōnē.
Phrasal Verbs
  • zone out
See zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: zone

name: end zone
content:
end zone

noun
 
/ˈend zəʊn/
 
/ˈend zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. the area at the end of an American football field into which the ball must be carried or passed in order to score pointsTopics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2
See end zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: end zone

name: hot zone
content:
hot zone

noun
 
/ˈhɒt zəʊn/
 
/ˈhɑːt zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area where a disease appeared for the first time or where there is a high risk of catching it
    • The hospital screens all patients who have recently visited hot zones.
    compare red zone (2)Topics Health problemsc2
Check pronunciation: hot zone

name: red zone
content:
red zone

noun
 
/ˈred zəʊn/
 
/ˈred zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. [singular] (in American football) the area within 20 yards of a team’s goal lineTopics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2
  2. [countable] an area where there is a high number of people carrying an infection and strict public health rules are in place
    • Tight restrictions remain in red zones.
    compare hot zoneTopics Health problemsc2
See red zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: red zone

name: war zone
content:
war zone

noun
 
/ˈwɔː zəʊn/
 
/ˈwɔːr zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. a region in which a war is being fought
    • We had accidentally strayed into the war zone.
    • Medical teams are on standby to fly out to the war zone.
See war zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: war zone

name: zone out
content:
zone out

phrasal verb
jump to other results
zone out
  1. (especially North American English, informal) to go to sleep, become unconscious or stop paying attention
    • I just zoned out for a moment.
See zone out in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: dead zone
content:
dead zone

noun
 
/ˈded zəʊn/
 
/ˈded zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. a place or a period of time in which nothing happens
    • The town is a cultural dead zone.
  2. an area that separates two places, groups of people, etc.
    • The UN is trying to maintain a dead zone between the warring groups.
  3. a place where a mobile phone does not work because no signal can be received
  4. (biology) an area of water in which animals cannot live because there is not enough oxygen
See dead zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: dead zone

name: drop zone
content:
drop zone

noun
 
/ˈdrɒp zəʊn/
 
/ˈdrɑːp zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. the area in which somebody/something should land after being dropped from an aircraft
See drop zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: drop zone

name: time zone
content:
time zone

noun
 
/ˈtaɪm zəʊn/
 
/ˈtaɪm zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. one of the 24 areas that the world is divided into, each with its own time that is one hour earlier than that of the time zone immediately to the east
    • a flight crossing several time zones
    Extra Examples
    • Vancouver is in the same time zone as Los Angeles.
    • We were crossing into a new time zone.
    Topics Timeb2
See time zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: time zone

name: danger zone
content:
danger zone

noun
 
/ˈdeɪndʒə zəʊn/
 
/ˈdeɪndʒər zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area in which there is a high risk of harm
    • They quickly evacuated people living in the danger zone.
    • Parking lots can be danger zones during the holiday season.
    • The sugar in these sauces is a real danger zone for dieters.
compare comfort zone
Check pronunciation: danger zone

name: frigid zone
content:
frigid zone

noun
 
/ˈfrɪdʒɪd zəʊn/
 
/ˈfrɪdʒɪd zəʊn/
[countable, usually singular] (specialist)
jump to other results
  1. the area inside the Arctic Circle or Antarctic Circle compare temperate zone, torrid zone
See frigid zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: frigid zone

name: strike zone
content:
strike zone

noun
 
/ˈstraɪk zəʊn/
 
/ˈstraɪk zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. (in baseball) the area between a batter’s upper arms and their knees, to which the ball must be pitched
See strike zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: strike zone

name: torrid zone
content:
torrid zone

noun
 
/ˈtɒrɪd zəʊn/
 
/ˈtɔːrɪd zəʊn/
[singular] (specialist)
jump to other results
  1. an area of the earth near the equator synonym the tropics
See torrid zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: torrid zone

name: comfort zone
content:
comfort zone

noun
 
/ˈkʌmfət zəʊn/
 
/ˈkʌmfərt zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. (sometimes disapproving) a place or situation in which you feel safe or comfortable, especially when you choose to stay in this situation instead of trying to work harder or achieve more
    • Stepping outside your comfort zone and trying new things can be a great experience.
    • We cannot afford to have anyone operating in a comfort zone.
    compare danger zone
    Extra Examples
    • Students are unwilling to step outside their comfort zone.
    • She's willing to venture outside her comfort zone.
    • I’ll tell you what drives me crazy—people who have talent but cruise along in the comfort zone.
  2. (approving) (especially in sport) a state in which you feel confident and are performing at your best
    • I knew if I could find my comfort zone I would be difficult to beat.
See comfort zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: comfort zone

name: crumple zone
content:
crumple zone

noun
 
/ˈkrʌmpl zəʊn/
 
/ˈkrʌmpl zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. the part of a car that is designed to crumple easily if there is an accident, to protect the people in the carTopics Transport by car or lorryc2
See crumple zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: crumple zone

name: neutral zone
content:
neutral zone

noun
 
/ˈnjuːtrəl zəʊn/
 
/ˈnuːtrəl zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. (in ice hockey) an area that covers the central part of the rink, between two blue lines
  2. (in American football) an imaginary area between the teams where no player except the centre is allowed to step until play has startedTopics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2
See neutral zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: neutral zone

name: no-fly zone
content:
no-fly zone

noun
 
/ˌnəʊ ˈflaɪ zəʊn/
 
/ˌnəʊ ˈflaɪ zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area above a country where planes from other countries are not allowed to fly, especially during a war
    • Fighter planes are being sent to enforce the UN no-fly zone.
    Topics Transport by airc1
See no-fly zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: no-fly zone

name: enterprise zone
content:
enterprise zone

noun
 
/ˈentəpraɪz zəʊn/
 
/ˈentərpraɪz zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area where the government encourages people to invest in new businesses, for example by offering lower taxes
    • Companies within enterprise zones are given special help.
    CultureEnterprise zones are usually city areas which have serious economic problems and where more jobs are badly needed.
See enterprise zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: enterprise zone

name: erogenous zone
content:
erogenous zone

noun
 
/ɪˈrɒdʒənəs zəʊn/
 
/ɪˈrɑːdʒənəs zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area of the body that gives sexual pleasure when it is touched
See erogenous zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: erogenous zone

name: exclusion zone
content:
exclusion zone

noun
 
/ɪkˈskluːʒn zəʊn/
 
/ɪkˈskluːʒn zəʊn/
jump to other results
  1. an area where people are not allowed to enter because it is dangerous or is used for secret activities
    • Armed forces have set up an exclusion zone around the island.
    • An enemy plane was shot down after it violated the exclusion zone.
    Topics War and conflictc2
See exclusion zone in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
